articles.headline: Pivoting From a War Footing, Obama Acts to Curtail Drones
articles.snippet: In a widely anticipated speech, President Obama said on Thursday that he would impose new curbs on the use of drone strikes, and he sought to renew his effort to close the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.
articles.abstract: In a widely anticipated speech, President Obama said on Thursday that he would impose new curbs on the use of drone strikes, and he sought to renew his effort to close the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly a dozen years after the hijackings that transformed America, President Obama said Thursday that it was time to narrow the scope of the grinding battle against terrorists and begin the transition to a day when the country will no longer be on a war footing.

articles.headline: Used Computer, $116,000 or Best Offer
articles.snippet: Apple-1 computers have sold for hundreds of thousands of dollars in recent auctions, a run-up reflecting the company’s mystique.
articles.abstract: Apple-1 computers have sold for hundreds of thousands of dollars in recent auctions, a run-up reflecting the company’s mystique.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than a decade ago, at a vintage computer fair in Silicon Valley, Dag Spicer had an opportunity to buy an original Apple-1 for $2,000. He passed. Any regrets? Not really, he said.

articles.headline: Bananas, Anyone? The Bluths Are Back
articles.snippet: “Arrested Development,” which became a cult hit after its cancellation in 2006, returns as a Netflix download series on Sunday.
articles.abstract: “Arrested Development,” which became a cult hit after its cancellation in 2006, returns as a Netflix download series on Sunday.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2003, when “Arrested Development” had its premiere on the Fox network, the country’s biggest comedy hits were the broad, safe “Everybody Loves Raymond” and “Friends.” Social networks like Twitter and Tumblr hadn’t been invented yet. Only 30 percent of American households had DVD players; only 3 percent had digital video recorders. Bingeing was a term associated with food, not television.

articles.headline: The Corrosive Effect of Apple’s Tax Avoidance
articles.snippet: In a Senate subcommittee hearing on Apple’s avoidance of paying taxes, John McCain and others tried to point out how unfair the current system was to domestic corporations.
articles.abstract: In a Senate subcommittee hearing on Apple’s avoidance of paying taxes, John McCain and others tried to point out how unfair the current system was to domestic corporations.
articles.lead_paragraph: The shameful thing about Apple Inc.’s ability to structure its business to avoid United States taxes was not that it did it. In fact, as Apple executives tried to point out at the Senate hearing at which their tax strategies were detailed, they could have chosen to pay much less in American taxes than they did.

articles.headline: Boy Scouts End Longtime Ban on Openly Gay Youths
articles.snippet: The Boy Scouts of America voted to allow openly gay youths as members, while continuing its policy of excluding openly gay adult leaders.
articles.abstract: The Boy Scouts of America voted to allow openly gay youths as members, while continuing its policy of excluding openly gay adult leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRAPEVINE, Tex. — The Boy Scouts of America on Thursday ended its longstanding policy of forbidding openly gay youths to participate in its activities, a step its chief executive called “compassionate, caring and kind.”

articles.headline: In Tax Overhaul Debate, Large vs. Small Companies
articles.snippet: As large companies fight for a cut in the official corporate tax rate, small businesses fear they will pay for it.
articles.abstract: As large companies fight for a cut in the official corporate tax rate, small businesses fear they will pay for it.
articles.lead_paragraph: In America’s contentious tax reform debate, it is seen as C-Suite versus Main Street.

articles.headline: New Terror Strategy Shifts C.I.A. Focus Back to Spying
articles.snippet: Some American officials and outside experts believe it could take years for an agency that has evolved into a paramilitary service to return to a focus on traditional espionage.
articles.abstract: Some American officials and outside experts believe it could take years for an agency that has evolved into a paramilitary service to return to a focus on traditional espionage.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For more than seven years, Mike — a lean, chain-smoking officer at the Central Intelligence Agency’s headquarters in Virginia — has managed the agency’s deadly campaign of armed drone strikes. As the head of the C.I.A.’s Counterterrorism Center, Mike wielded tremendous power in hundreds of decisions over who lived and died in far-off lands.

articles.headline: Banks’ Lobbyists Help in Drafting Financial Bills
articles.snippet: Citigroup’s ideas were reflected in more than 70 lines of one 85-line bill.
articles.abstract: Citigroup’s ideas were reflected in more than 70 lines of one 85-line bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Bank lobbyists are not leaving it to lawmakers to draft legislation that softens financial regulations. Instead, the lobbyists are helping to write it themselves.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Ben Protess

articles.headline: California Puts Tentative Price on Health Policies Under New Law
articles.snippet: Thirteen insurers had been chosen to sell policies through the insurance marketplace — or exchange — being created under the law.
articles.abstract: Thirteen insurers had been chosen to sell policies through the insurance marketplace — or exchange — being created under the law.
articles.lead_paragraph: California, widely seen as a model for how individuals will buy health insurance under the new health care law, announced Thursday that 13 insurers had been chosen to sell policies through the insurance marketplace — or exchange — being created under the law.

articles.headline: Racing the Clock and a Storm: A Way of Life in Tornado Alley
articles.snippet: In the breeding ground of Oklahoma tornadoes, people prepare for the season with the care that the defensive coordinator for their Sooners prepares for the inevitable autumn.
articles.abstract: In the breeding ground of Oklahoma tornadoes, people prepare for the season with the care that the defensive coordinator for their Sooners prepares for the inevitable autumn.
articles.byline: By Dan Barry and John Schwartz

articles.headline: China Plans to Reduce the State’s Role in the Economy
articles.snippet: After years of relying on state spending to supercharge growth, China’s new prime minister, Li Keqiang, said the government would seek to unleash the nation’s creative energies.
articles.abstract: After years of relying on state spending to supercharge growth, China’s new prime minister, Li Keqiang, said the government would seek to unleash the nation’s creative energies.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — The Chinese government is planning for private businesses and market forces to play a larger role in its economy, in a major policy shift intended to improve living conditions for the middle class and to make China an even stronger competitor on the global stage.
articles.byline: By David Barboza and Chris Buckley
